author: Staff Reporter
text:
Nurses attached to the Dharmapuri Medical College Hospital abstained from work and joined the ongoing statewide protest called by government employees here on Thursday.

The protesters called for regularisation of the pay roll of nurses appointed on ad-hoc basis and those have completed six years of service.

Pension scheme

The protesters also called for dropping of the new contributory pension scheme and reversal to the status quo in the pension scheme.

Among the demands included service recognition of contract nurses and provision of promotion based on the years of work put in.

The Tamil Nadu Nurses’ Association has also proposed to take the strike to the next level if their demands are not met at the earliest.

Salem Staff Reporter adds:

The indefinite strike by government employees has affected the public at large as the police erected barricades at the entrance of the Collectorate and prevented the entry of the protestors.

This affected the public who came to the Collectorate as the police verified their identification cards and allowed them to enter the premises.

The protesting employees assembled in large numbers in Nattamai Kazhagam building premises in the morning.

About 50 employees wanted them to be permitted to meet the Collector which was denied by the police.

Barricades

A team led by Deputy Commissioner of Police (Law and Order) S. Selvaraj, and Assistant Commissioner of Police Ravindran erected barricades outside the Collectorate.

As the employees assembled in front of the Collectorate, the public faced inconvenience in entering the premises.

Slogans raised

Protestors raised slogans demanding that the Collector invite them for talks and fulfil their 20-point demands. Many people who came to the Collectorate for getting various works done have to leave the premises due to the protest.
title: Nurses join strike in Dharmapuri district
